17 hours ago, RA3236 said:

It sounds as if you have an upside down command module. Look at it, flip it and then try.

I'm not sure this is a backwards command module/probe core.  If that was the case, and it was the control-from-here part, then the navball prograde marker would already be shown that way and if the ship was already pointing at it, then hitting "prograde hold" wouldn't change anything.

Instead, I think this is just an example of the poor design of the whole "hold pointing in direction X" system.  The system has no self-control.  It always slams the ship around to the fullest extent of its control authority, resulting in major overshoots and oscillations, and much wastage of RCS if you have that.  So the #1 rule of using this system is NEVER let it reorient the ship itself.  Instead, point the ship where you want manually and then tell it to hold there.  But the #2 rule is not to rely on this.  If you don't have the ship pointed EXACTLY in the desired direction, the hamfisted system will slam it over, overshoot the mark, slam it back the other way, etc., often diverging from the desired orientation instead of converging to it.  Occasionally this doesn't happen and the system does an adequate job of holding that direction.  But usually not.

So the #3 rule of the direction-holding system is NOT TO USE IT.  Instead, point the ship in the desired direction manually and keep the thing in stability mode to hold it there.  This works MUCH better.

For an interesting demonstration of the worthlessness of the stock system, install MJ and compare the results of its SmartASS app to the stock system.  Tell, SmartASS to point in a given direction and it gives the ship a gentle nudge in that direction, coasts until it gets there, then stops, using only the minimum RCS required.  The stock system, OTOH, oscillates badly as described above.  Tell SmartASS to hold a given direction after you point there manually and it does, where as all bets are off with the stock system.   Which is exactly what you get if you do it all manually and just use stability mode.

@Geschosskopf I noticed exactly this issue yesterday.  My lander can's electricity reserves would deplete much more quickly if I set SAS to hold retrograde versus hold heading.  Turned out the hold retrograde setting was applying lots of little corrections, using up the precious little electricity I had left at an alarming rate (was down to just the lander can, a heat shield, and a parachute... no solar panels left on the craft).  As I wasn't in a situation where retrograde was changing quickly, I just set SAS to hold heading instead.  Finally ended up shutting everything down and just coasting instead to conserve power for when it was needed.
